title-group.article-title: Investigating the relationship between inaccurate blood alcohol concentration estimates, harm and other negative consequences

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Dominique de Andrade, School of Psychology, Faculty of Health, Deakin University, Locked Bag 20001, Geelong, Victoria 3220, Australia. Email: d.deandrade@deakin.edu.au

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2022 The Authors. Drug and Alcohol Review published by John Wiley & Sons Australia, Ltd on behalf of Australasian Professional Society on Alcohol and other Drugs.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Alcohol‐related harms place a significant burden on the Australian economy and health‐care system. The current study aims to: (i) explore the relationship between blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and self‐estimated blood alcohol concentration (EBAC); and (ii) determine whether BAC underestimation is related to an increased risk of experiencing physical aggression, verbal aggression, drink driving, ejection from a venue or refusal of service.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Patron street surveys were conducted in four night‐time entertainment precincts (NEP) across Queensland, Australia, between June 2016 and November 2018. Participants (N = 2144) reported on their EBAC and recent negative or harmful experiences in NEPs. BAC was measured via a breathalyser. Paired samples t tests were conducted to determine if patrons' BAC and EBAC were significantly different. Logistic regressions were conducted to examine whether BAC underestimation is a significant predictor of harm and negative outcomes.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Analyses identified a small, significant difference between patron's BAC and EBAC. Patrons with a low BAC were more likely to overestimate their BAC, while patrons with higher BACs were more likely to underestimate their BAC. Moderately intoxicated patrons had the most precise BAC estimations. Patrons with a high BAC and who underestimated their intoxication level were more likely to have been recently ejected from licensed venues, compared to accurate estimators or over‐estimators.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions
sec.p: Overall, patrons are poor evaluators of their own intoxication level, which may have implications for their experiences in NEPs. The findings highlight the need for improved BAC education for patrons.

institution-wrap.institution: Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education

p.mixed-citation: de AndradeD, ButtonK, CoomberK, TaylorN, FerrisJ, CurtisA, et al. Investigating the relationship between inaccurate blood alcohol concentration estimates, harm and other negative consequences. Drug Alcohol Rev. 2023;42(2):467–475. 10.1111/dar.1356936449348PMC10286749

fn.p: Funding information Australian Rechabites Foundation; Australian Research Council, Grant/Award Number: Linkage/LP160100067; Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education; Lives Lived Well; Queensland Government

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In Australian night‐time entertainment precincts (NEP), alcohol‐related harms place an immense, yet preventable burden on patrons, emergency services and venue staff [1]. One in four Australians report consuming more than four standard drinks on a single occasion at least monthly, which is a consumption rate directly associated with acute alcohol‐related harms [2]. It is estimated that alcohol consumption is a contributing factor in up to 73% of all assaults and 30% of car crashes involving serious injury [3, 4]. While there is a clear association between alcohol consumption and harm, the relationship is complex, with research demonstrating substantial individual differences in people's behavioural response to alcohol [5, 6]. Self‐estimated blood or breath alcohol concentration is one such individual characteristic that has been implicated in acute alcohol‐related harms [7, 8]. Estimated blood alcohol concentration (EBAC) is an individual's perceived level of intoxication, and is influenced by the person's experiences, expectations and behavioural cues [9]. The term ‘blood alcohol concentration’ (BAC) is frequently used when referring to the concentration of alcohol in one's breath and, while not as accurate, is an accepted proxy. Many modern breathalysers can convert breath alcohol concentration (BrAC) to an estimate of BAC.

Despite the tangible physiological and psychological cues experienced when consuming alcohol, research suggests that the relationship between BAC and EBAC is not linear [10, 11]. While there is some evidence that drinkers are more likely to overestimate their BAC [11, 12], a growing number of studies have found that drinkers tend to either accurately estimate or slightly overestimate their intoxication level at lower BACs, whereas those with a higher BAC tend to markedly underestimate their intoxication level [13, 14, 15]. One Australian field‐based study investigating the relationship between individual's BAC and EBAC, found that at a low BAC, individuals were somewhat sensitive to increases in intoxication level [16]. However, as BAC increased, this sensitivity continued to dissipate to the point where patrons could no longer assess any difference created by consuming additional beverages, thereby resulting in significant BAC underestimation. Despite the limitations, existing literature indicates that individuals are generally poor evaluators of their own degree of impairment, especially at higher intoxication levels.

The relationship between EBAC and harm has been studied sporadically over recent decades. Early laboratory studies determined that perceived intoxication level was associated with performance impairment, especially relating to psychomotor skills such as reaction and anticipation time [17, 18]. Studies examining the relationship between inaccurate BAC estimates and harm have predominantly focused on drink‐driving behaviours. One influential study in this area employed roadside surveys to 2857 night‐time drivers and found that 94% of drivers with a BAC over 0.10 g/dl underestimated their intoxication level [19]. Moreover, laboratory studies have demonstrated that risk‐taking in driving simulator tasks increases when subjects underestimate their BAC, even after controlling for objective BAC [7, 20]. The few existing field‐based studies tend to look at individual's willingness to drive [21, 22]. One study investigating young Australian's willingness to drive after a multi‐day music festival, determined that individuals with a lower EBAC felt safer to drive than those with a higher EBAC [22]. These findings further suggest that inaccurate BAC estimation can substantially impact judgement.

Very few studies have investigated the impact of inaccurate BAC estimates on outcomes other than drink driving. One early laboratory study established the relationship between EBAC and aggression by demonstrating that male social drinkers who believed that they had consumed alcohol were more aggressive than males who believed that they had consumed a non‐alcoholic drink [23]. The few existing studies which have explicitly examined the relationship between EBAC and aggressive behaviour yield mixed results. One laboratory study found that objective BrAC was predictive of aggressive responses in men whereas subjective BrAC was not [24]. Conversely, another laboratory study found that both estimated and objective BAC were predictive of aggression in men who were exposed to high provocation [25]. Furthermore, the validity of these findings may be compromised due to ethical constraints.

Another consequence of inaccurate BAC estimation may be that patrons are either refused service or ejected from the venue. Little research has focused on the predictors of these outcomes. Research by Droste et al. found that as BAC increases, patrons become worse at estimating the level of their own intoxication whereas trained, sober observers remain relatively accurate [10]. When patrons significantly underestimate their BAC, their ability to recognise the point at which it is not safe to continue drinking is also likely diminished. In such instances, trained venue staff generally take on the responsibility of managing heavily intoxicated individuals [26].

sec.title: The present study
sec.p: The limited body of literature suggests that inaccurate BAC estimation can significantly impact individual's risk‐perceptions, expectations, decision‐making and psychomotor skills. Further, existing studies generally involve small, specific sub‐populations, are predominantly laboratory based and focus almost exclusively on drink‐driving behaviour. Laboratory studies do not capture drinking in the natural environment and very few field‐based studies have been conducted. The current study intends to address these gaps in the literature by using a large systematic random sample of Australian nightlife patrons. Based loosely on Kaestle et al.'s study [16], we aimed to investigate the relationship between actual BAC and EBAC in patrons of four Australian NEPs. Further, we aimed to determine whether BAC underestimation is associated with the experience of harm.

It was hypothesised that for patrons of NEPs:
There would be a statistically significant difference between patron's BAC and EBAC.
BAC underestimation would be significantly associated with recent experiences of: (i) driving a vehicle under the influence of alcohol; (ii) experiencing physical aggression in and around licensed venues; (iii) experiencing verbal aggression in and around licensed venues; (iv) being ejected from a licensed venue while under the influence of alcohol; and (v) being refused service in a licensed venue while under the influence of alcohol.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Fortitude Valley is in inner‐city Brisbane, the capital city of Queensland, Australia, and is the busiest NEP in Queensland. Nearby, approximately 3 km away, in the inner west of Brisbane, West End is a small NEP with a number of small‐ to medium‐sized bars. Cairns NEP is a well‐known tourist destination located in far north Queensland. Surfers Paradise is in south‐east Queensland in the Gold Coast and is also a popular tourist destination, with a dense NEP. Unlike West End NEP, Fortitude Valley, Cairns and Surfers Paradise NEPs have been deemed designated NEPs or ‘Safe Night Precincts’ by the Queensland Government, supported by additional resourcing (e.g., street care support services, policing).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were recruited from one of the four outlined Queensland NEPs as a part of a broader study investigating the effectiveness of the Queensland Government's Tackling Alcohol‐Fuelled Violence Policy [27, 28]. Participants were only interviewed if they were 18 years of age or older (the legal drinking age in Australia). The interviewers approached 6356 individuals, with surveys being completed by 4702 participants (74% participation rate). For the current study, 209 participants were removed as they responded ‘I don't know’ when asked to estimate their EBAC. A further 2182 participants were removed due to missing data (2043 missing EBAC, 555 missing BAC, 416 missing both). Of the missing EBAC responses, 1021 were due to the first iteration of the survey not including the EBAC question (survey was modified in August 2016). The remaining missing data was largely due to participants not consenting to the breathalyser test or not wanting to estimate their BAC. After testing for outliers, a further 4 BAC scores and 24 EBAC scores were removed. Finally, we removed 139 participants who appeared to have not consumed alcohol prior to their interview and would therefore accurately estimate their BAC to be 0.000. These participants indicated that they did not ‘pre‐drink’, had a BAC reading of 0.000 and estimated their BAC to be 0.000 when interviewed. Following these exclusions, there were 2144 participants. Table 1 shows the number of patrons included from each district.

caption.p: Sample size and demographics across the four entertainment districts

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Ethical approval for the study was provided by Research Ethics Committees at Deakin University (2011‐095), The University of Queensland (2016001021) and James Cook University (H6726). The patron interviews were designed to gather a systematic random sample. Deakin University research teams of four or more researchers sampled participants by approaching every third individual in busy thoroughfares of each district. Participants were asked if they would be willing to complete the interview, which took approximately 5 min. If patrons refused, were moving between locations or queuing at a venue, a 3 min brief version of the interview was offered. Following verbal consent, patrons were given a business card containing the contact details of the study investigators and ethics committee. Data were collected via iPod Touches and iPhone devices using Tap Forms Software. At the conclusion of the survey, participants were asked to verbally consent to a breathalyser test. The breathalyser model was an Andatech Prodigy S, calibrated 6‐monthly. We utilised the BAC setting, whereby the breathalyser converted the BrAC reading to BAC. To maintain safety of the research team, potential participants were not approached if they were deemed too intoxicated to provide informed consent [29]. Data collection occurred on Saturday nights either monthly (Fortitude Valley and Cairns) or bi‐monthly (West End and Surfers Paradise) between 10 PM and 4 AM. Recruitment occurred between 11 June 2016 and 18 November 2018.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The patron interview was comprised of seven sections and included questions regarding participant demographics, the current night out and alcohol‐related consequences. The brief interview included a smaller subsection of these questions. The specific items utilised in the current study are discussed further.

sec.title: Breath alcohol concentration
sec.p: BAC was measured as a continuous variable and drawn from the BAC sample taken at the time of the interview. For the analyses, BAC was recoded into five categories similar to groupings specified by Droste et al. [9] including: sober (0.000 g/dl); slightly intoxicated (0.001–0.049 g/dl); moderately intoxicated (0.050–0.079 g/dl); intoxicated (0.080–0.119 g/dl); and heavily intoxicated (0.120 g/dl and above).

sec.title: Estimated breath alcohol concentration
sec.p: EBAC was measured as a continuous variable and was obtained by asking participants to estimate what they thought their BAC was at the time of the interview.

sec.title: Inaccurate BAC estimate
sec.p: A difference variable was created for the current study (continuous BAC variable minus continuous EBAC variable), to reflect the accuracy of patron's BAC estimations. A negative score was indicative of overestimation, whereas a positive score was indicative of an underestimation. The continuous difference variable was then recoded into a dichotomous variable (accurate/overestimation = 0; underestimation = 1). BAC underestimation was classified as anyone with a difference variable of ≥0.01.

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: Covariates included age as a continuous variable and gender as a categorical variable (female = 0; male = 1).

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: All dependent variables were initially measured as scale variables. Across separate questions, participants were asked how many times in the past 3 months they had experienced the following events while under the influence of alcohol: physical aggression in an NEP (as victim or aggressor); verbal aggression in an NEP (as victim or aggressor); drink driving; ejections from a licensed venue; refusal of service in a licensed venue. For the current study, responses were recoded into dichotomous variables (≥1 event = ‘yes’; 0 events = ‘no’).

sec.title: Analytic strategy
sec.p: To address the first hypothesis, a paired samples t test was conducted to determine whether there was a significant difference between participant's BAC and EBAC. A paired samples t test was then conducted for each of the five previously specified BAC categories, to assess the difference between actual BAC and EBAC across different levels of intoxication. A Bonferroni correction was applied, with an alpha level of 0.01 used to determine significance [30]. All participants were included in this analysis. To address hypothesis two, a series of adjusted logistic regressions were undertaken to determine whether BAC estimation accuracy is a significant predictor of the five aforementioned harms/negative outcomes. Age and gender were included as covariates. Participants who completed the brief interview (n = 796) did not answer the questions concerning drink‐driving, ejection from venue or refusal of service, so were not included in those analyses. Complete case analysis was undertaken, due to missing data from respondents (resulting in differing participant numbers for each analysis). All analyses were conducted using IBM SPSS Statistics 27.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Assumptions were met for the paired samples t tests and logistic regression analyses. For the sample overall, the average BAC was 0.09 g/dl (SD = 0.06 g/dl) and the average EBAC was 0.08 g/dl (SD = 0.05 g/dl). Figure 1 depicts the relationship between BAC and inaccurate BAC estimate. The paired sample t test determined that participants' BAC was significantly different from their estimated BAC, t(2143) = 7.717, p < 0.001. Individuals were more likely to marginally underestimate their intoxication, with participants' BAC being on average, 0.01 g/dl greater than their EBAC. Based on benchmarks suggested by Cohen [31], the effect size for this analysis was small, d = 0.17, 95% confidence interval [0.12, 0.21].

caption.p: The relationship between BAC and inaccurate BAC estimate (BAC minus EBAC). BAC, blood alcohol concentration; EBAC, estimated blood alcohol concentration

sec.p: Table 2 shows the results of the paired sample t tests which assessed the difference between participant's BAC and EBAC, across the different levels of intoxication. While a significant difference was found for each BAC category, the effect sizes differed substantially. Patrons in the sober group and slightly intoxicated group were more likely to overestimate their BAC, with moderate to large effect sizes. Patrons in the moderately intoxicated group were also more likely to overestimate their BAC, however, the effect size was small. Those in the intoxicated group were more likely to underestimate their BAC. The effect size was small to moderate. Finally, the patrons in the heavily intoxicated group were more likely to underestimate their BAC. The corresponding effect size was large.

caption.p: Paired sample t test results comparing patron's BAC and EBAC across BAC categories

fn.p: Abbreviations: BAC, blood alcohol concentration; CI, confidence interval; EBAC, estimated blood alcohol concentration; intox, intoxicated.
A negative mean value indicates an overestimation of BAC, a positive value indicates an underestimation of BAC.

sec.p: Table 3 shows the results of the five logistic regression models that were conducted with the dichotomous inaccurate BAC estimate measure as the main predictor. BAC underestimation was not a significant predictor of patron's recent engagement in physical aggression, verbal aggression, drink‐driving or refusal of service. However, after controlling for age and gender, participants who underestimated their BAC were 1.56 times more likely to have been ejected from a licensed premise in the past 3 months than those who accurately or overestimated their BAC.

caption.p: Logistic regression analyses on BAC underestimation and harm/negative outcomes

fn.p: Note: For BAC difference, underestimation is the target group. All models controlled for age and gender.
Abbreviations: AOR, adjusted odds ratio; BAC, blood alcohol concentration; CI, confidence interval.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The aim of the current study was to investigate the relationship between actual BAC and EBAC and to establish whether inaccurate BAC estimates were associated with harm. The findings supported the first hypothesis, as there were notable differences between patron's actual BAC and estimated BAC, particularly at higher levels of intoxication. The findings of the current study also partly supported the second hypothesis, as patrons who underestimated their BAC were significantly more likely to have a recent history of being ejected from a licensed premises. However, BAC underestimation did not increase the likelihood of being refused service, experiencing physical and verbal aggression or drink‐driving.

When examining the sample as a whole, the difference between patron's actual BAC and EBAC was trivial. However, when patrons were separated into categories based on their BAC level, several meaningful differences emerged. Those who were sober, slightly intoxicated and moderately intoxicated were more likely to overestimate their BAC. Although the magnitude of overestimation was substantially smaller in the moderately intoxicated patrons, which indicated that they had more precise estimates. In contrast, intoxicated and heavily intoxicated patrons (i.e., BAC >0.079 g/dl) were more likely to underestimate their BAC. This relationship trajectory was largely consistent with previous findings [15, 16]. The contradictory findings on the relationship between BAC and EBAC in earlier research may have, in part, been due to researchers grouping all levels of intoxication together. This oversimplification may have inadvertently resulted in researchers overlooking the complex dynamics of the relationship at different BAC levels.

Unexpectedly, sober patrons were not the most accurate estimators of intoxication level. Rather, those who were moderately intoxicated (i.e., BAC of 0.050 to 0.079 g/dl) had on average, the most precise BAC estimates. One study determined that patrons who ‘pre‐drank’ before arriving at the bar were more likely to overestimate their BAC as they did not account for the amount of time that had passed during their drinking session [32]. A similar phenomenon may explain why individuals with no alcohol in their system assumed that they were not completely sober. If patrons only consumed a limited number of drinks over the course of the night, they may have vastly underestimated the rate at which their body metabolised the alcohol, resulting in overestimation.

Moreover, research suggests that at a BAC of 0.050 g/dl, people become less vigilant and experience impaired psychomotor skills and drowsiness [33]. Moderately intoxicated patrons may have relatively accurate BAC estimates as they are simultaneously experiencing numerous physiological changes. Furthermore, in Australia, the legal driving limit is under 0.050 g/dl. Information available to the general public pertaining to BAC tends to focus exclusively on this level (e.g., drinking one standard drink per hour should keep you below the legal limit [34];). As such, this is likely the intoxication level patrons are most familiar with. Finally, patrons who were heavily intoxicated procured the largest discrepancy between BAC and EBAC. In accordance with prior research findings, higher BrAC or BACs were associated with substantial underestimation, suggesting that patron's sensitivity to increasing intoxication levels diminishes significantly [15, 35].

In contrast to previous research findings, those who underestimated their BAC were not more likely to have driven under the influence of alcohol compared to those who accurately or overestimated their intoxication. Existing literature focuses on the impacts of BAC underestimation on risk‐taking while driving (i.e., in a driving simulator [7];). One plausible explanation of the current study's findings may be that BAC underestimation does not affect the decision to engage in drink‐driving, rather, it may only influence risk‐taking and impairment while driving. Prior research has identified that impulsivity, increased objective intoxication, drug‐use and gender are significant predictors of drink‐driving [36, 37]. These factors evidently play a more pivotal role in individuals' engagement in drink‐driving compared to inaccurate BAC estimates. Further, there is likely a proportion of participants that will always take public transport or Ubers/taxis when going out to drink (i.e., never drive), resulting in a floor effect.

In relation to the impact of inaccurate BAC estimates on aggression, BAC underestimation did not increase the likelihood of having recently experienced either physical or verbal aggression. As previously mentioned, the relationship between aggression and subjective intoxication is unclear. There are more salient findings in the existing literature pertaining to the relationship between alcohol use and aggression. Heavy episodic drinking and trait aggression are important explanatory factors in this relationship [38, 39, 40]. It is therefore likely that the experience of alcohol‐related aggression is more contingent upon the acute pharmacological effects of alcohol and dispositional aggression than on subjective intoxication.

In relation to the second hypothesis, while patrons who underestimated their BAC were not more likely to have been refused service, they were considerably more likely to have a history of being ejected from licensed venues. This follows logically from the findings that those who underestimated their BAC were the most intoxicated patrons. It also corresponds to the findings identified by Droste et al. [8]. As patron's intoxication level continues to increase, they become less able to identify their level of impairment. Therefore the venue's responsibility regarding safe consumption and patron monitoring becomes more important.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: Patrons are also typically unaware of the alcohol concentration in different beverages, their rate of consumption, metabolism and the corresponding effect on BAC [41]. Despite this, patrons are expected to understand their level of intoxication and make decisions accordingly. While BAC education in Australia is typically focused on the legal drink‐driving limit, research suggests that social drinkers can learn to successfully gauge their level of intoxication [42]. This can be achieved by a combination of internal (paying attention to cues at different BAC levels) and external (BAC education) training. At a community level, improved BAC education may lessen the burden placed on venue staff and emergency services as it could improve consumer's ability to monitor their own intoxication. At an individual level, more targeted BAC education interventions may be beneficial in reducing alcohol misuse and related harm (e.g., Quikfix [43];). The Quikfix program reduces the risk of future alcohol‐related harm by providing targeted support and education to young people that have experienced harm on nights out.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: The current study has four clear limitations. First, the measure of underestimation was based on a single night whereas outcome measures were based on patrons' experiences in the previous 3 months. This potentially weakens the relationship between BAC underestimation and harm in the current study. Second, there was a substantial amount of missing data which may have reduced the representativeness of the sample. Third, while the survey had a good response rate, there were a proportion of patrons who refused to partake in the survey, who may be intrinsically different to participants [44]. Finally, this form of interview can be subject to self‐presentation bias. Despite these limitations, this study had a number of strengths including: data collection method (i.e., street surveys in the natural drinking environment), recruitment strategy (resulting in a random sample) and the diverse range of Australian NEPs included.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Patrons tend to be poor evaluators of their own intoxication level, especially at higher levels of BAC. The findings from this study highlight the need for improved BAC education at both an individual and community level. While inaccurate BAC estimates were not associated with the experience of harm, this relationship should be further investigated in future research by examining harms that occur on the same night that patrons estimate their BAC.

sec.title: FUNDING INFORMATION
sec.p: The QUANTEM project was funded by an Australian Research Council Linkage grant (LP160100067), the Queensland Government, Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education, Australian Rechabites Foundation and Lives Lived Well.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: PM, JF and KC conceived the street survey and data collection procedure. PM, NT and DdA collected data. PM, DdA, NT, KC and KB conceived and designed the study. KB conducted data analysis. PM, DdA, NT, KC, AC and KB critically reviewed thedata analysis and interpretation. DdA and KB drafted the manuscript. Allauthors contributed with critical edits to the manuscript's content. All authors approved the final version of the manuscript.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors confirm that there are no financial declarations to be made, and no competing interests, relevant to this study. Funding bodies had no involvement in the decision to publish this study. Dominique de Andrade and Ashlee Curtis receive funding from Barwon Health and the Commonwealth Department of Health. Kerri Coomber receives funding from Australian Research Council, Queensland Government and Northern Territory Government. Jason Ferris receives funding from Australian Research Council and Australian National Health and Medical Research Council, funding from QLD Government, Department of Health, Tasmanian Department of Health, Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education, Criminology Research Council, VicHealth, travel and related costs from Queensland Police Service. Peter G. Miller receives funding from Barwon Health, Australian Research Council and Australian National Health and Medical Research Council, grants from NSW Government, National Drug Law Enforcement Research Fund, Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education, Cancer Council Victoria, Central Australian Aboriginal Congress, Northern Territory government, Australian Rechabites Foundation, Northern Territory Primary Health Network, Lives Lived Well, Queensland government and Australian Drug Foundation, travel and related costs from Queensland Police Service, Queensland Office of Liquor Gaming and Racing and the Australasian Drug Strategy Conference. Peter G. Miller contribution in this study is covered by ARC Discovery Grant DP150100441. He has acted as a paid expert witness on behalf of a licensed venue and a security firm.
